Resolved Question Show me another » I was in McDonalds barefoot and slipped on the floor that was being mopped and hurt my back. Do I have a case? The manager told me that they were not responsible because a sign on the door says that shoes must be worn and because a wet floor sign was on the floor. 3 years ago Report Abuse by Sheriam Member since: 13 December 2006 Total points: 51,560 (Level 7) Add Contact Block
Best Answer - Chosen by Voters If you indeed like going barefoot in public, as the list of questions someone else quoted suggests, then please don't ask questions that perpetuate the *myths* that going barefoot is dangerous, that barefooters are likely to sue when they themselves mess up by not watching where they're going, and that going barefoot should be against the law and/or insurance regulations.
Looking at your previous questions, I don't for a moment believe this actually happened to you. Apart from your'obsession with going barefoot'and making up barefoot questions to satisfy this, bare feet can be slippery on a wet floor, but when you're barefoot you are more aware of where you walk. You will feel immediately that the floor is wet so even if you hadn't seen the'wet floor'sign (which are usually placed so that they're hard to miss) you probably wouldn't have slipped. I've been barefoot for 13 years -in many McDonalds and other places, they don't have signs against bare feet here in Europe- and I've never slipped. I *have* slipped back when I was still wearing shoes, with dressy leather-soled shoes I didn't feel how slick the floor was until it was too late. (still didn't sue or even think of suing, I take my own responsibility for where I walk, as everyone should).
And the signs on US stores reflect store/company policy only; other barefooters have checked and contrary to popular belief, there are NO laws against going barefoot in stores and restaurants. Any stores or restaurants that post signs saying'by order of the Health Department'are lying -or as McDonalds corporate said when confronted with the letters proving there were no State laws, it referred to their own internal Health Department and not the State or county ones (which is misleading since of course the public thinks it's the government rather than the company's HD...)
Also barefooters have checked many insurance policies and while we haven't read them all -it's much harder to prove a negative with insurance than with the government, where there is a known number of States- we have NEVER found an insurance policy that DID require or even recommended footwear for customers.
Fortunately both Health Departments and insurance companies seem to know better about the *real* risk of going barefoot (very, very small) than the general public. I can only hope that those of the public who read this will check the links below and educate themselves :-) Source(s): No laws against going barefoot in stores and restaurants: http://www.barefooters.org/health-dept More general info about going barefoot on the main page: http://www.barefooters.org and 13 years of going barefoot always and everywhere, without any trouble. 3 years ago Report Abuse 40% 2 Votes Action Bar: 1 stars - mark this as Interesting! Member since: 02 April 2006 Total points: 11 (Level 1) Add Contact Block You can try to sue for negligence, because actually, they are not suppose to be mopping during business hours, while there are customers in the store. When I was little, I went into a MacDonald's, where they were mopping and they had the sign up, and I slipped and fell. My parents then sued for negligence, and we ended up settling out of court. Contact you a lawyer, or you can proceed with the case pro- se. Also, start going to the doctor, for treatment of your back, to help strength you case. Good luck. 3 years ago Report Abuse 0% 0 Votes by Anon28 Member since: 27 May 2006 Total points: 4,822 (Level 4) Add Contact Block This would be a case in negligence. You would have to show that they were in some way unreasonable, and if there was a wet floor sign up, that does make it hard for you.
Also, even if they WERE negligent, there is the issue of comparative negligence, meaning were you unreasonable, leading to your injuries. The fact that there is a"no shirt, no shoes"is unlikely to matter for this. The question is whether a reasonable person would go into a McDonald's without shoes, and whether that contributed to your injury. Depending on what jurisdiction you are in, this can have one of two effects:
1) pure comparative negligence jurisdiction: If the jury finds you are liable for 75% of your injury, and they are for 25%, they have to pay you 25% of your damages.
2) modified comparative negligence jurisdiction: if you are found to be 50%+ liable, you get nothing.
They may also bring up an issue of"duty."You can only be liable for negligence if you have a duty to not be negligent towards the injured person. They can claim that since they say not to come in without shoes, they have no duty to people who do. However, there is general public access. It would be an interesting case.
At the end of the day, you likely have no case. there was pretty clear negligence on your part by not wearing shoes, and the hypo doesn't point to any particularly negligent action on their part (they have to wash the floor sometime.) In particular, it sounds like if you are in a modified comparative liability jurisdiction, you would be wasting your time. Better to just move on. Sorry. Feel better. Source(s): Just finished law school. 3 years ago Report Abuse 0% 0 Votes 1 person rated this as good by John73 Member since: 21 June 2006 Total points: 7,907 (Level 5) Add Contact Block No, you don't have a case, but you wouldn't likely do very well even if you had shoes on. If a wet floor sign is posted when employees are mopping the floor, that's really the best McDonald's can do. While I am sure the restaurant tries to avoid mopping during business hours, circumstances like a spilled soda may lead to daytime mopping. In short, McDonald's was not negligent, so you would lose.
If McDonald's was negligent, then the issue of your bare feet would come up as a form of comparative negligence. The restaurant's negligence would be compared to your negligence in failing to obey the NS3 instructions. In the end, I don't think the restaurant was negligent, so this issue should not even need to be considered, but if it was to be considered, I would expect an unfavorable response from a jury. 3 years ago Report Abuse 0% 0 Votes by laughter... Member since: 25 April 2006 Total points: 176,820 (Level 7) Badge Image: Add Contact Block There are a couple principles involved. The first is negligence. McD's is not a guarantor of your safety. Any claim would have to be based on some claim of negligence. You didn't mention any. The other is called"assumption of the risk."If you knowingly encounter a hazard, (by seeing the wet floor and walking on it) you assume the risk of any resulting injury. Then there is comparative negligence. If you did not look where you were going, then you are at least as much as fault as the person that mopped the floor. That being said, taking legal advice from the person you might have a claim against is generally unwise. No rule of law requires that person to agree with you or to give good advice even if they had intentionally injured you. If you want legal advice, hire a lawyer instead of asking the manager of a McDs. If you want a burger, go to McDs instead of to your lawyer. 3 years ago Report Abuse 0% 0 Votes by jackson Member since: 18 March 2006 Total points: 44,321 (Level 7) Add Contact Block No case......

First... you didn't belong PAST the threshold because you were without shoes.

Third... they PROBABLY had a"wet floor"sign, which pretty much absolves them of any wrong-doing as slippery situation was clear.
In order to win, you'd have to prove they are liable for you slipping... in a place you didn't belong..... in a condition you didn't belong.... ignoring the situation in which you were personally responsible. 3 years ago Report Abuse 0% 0 Votes 4 people rated this as good by (Ken doll) Member since: 12 June 2008 Total points: 2,311 (Level 3) Add Contact Block You sure like bare feet, don't you?:
